content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. My mind just won’t stop racing at night, and I can’t seem to shut it off. I’m feeling really stressed about work and worrying that I might lose my job. It’s been tough, and I’m not sure how to deal with it.

That's a lot to deal with—a racing mind, stress about work, and sleep troubles. It's understandable that all of this is weighing on you. What do you think has been the hardest part for you in managing this stress and your sleep lately?

I think the hardest part is just feeling stuck. I lay awake thinking about all the things that could go wrong, like losing my job and not being able to take care of my family. It’s like this never-ending loop in my head, and I don’t know how to stop it.

It sounds overwhelming to feel stuck in a loop of worries about work and family—the weight of those responsibilities can be intense. You care deeply about your family and want to make sure they're okay, but that pressure seems to make it harder to find peace at night. How do you usually try to handle these thoughts when they come up?

I honestly don’t feel like I handle them all that well. I just end up lying there, staring at the ceiling, and the thoughts just spiral. Sometimes I’ll try to distract myself by scrolling on my phone, but it doesn’t really help—it just keeps me awake longer.

It sounds frustrating to try to distract yourself only to feel more awake and still caught in those spiraling thoughts. You’re really trying to manage this on your own, even though it hasn’t been easy. What do you think might be keeping you from finding something that helps you quiet your mind at night?

I think it’s just the stress being so constant—it feels like there’s no escape from it. Even when I try to relax, it’s like my brain refuses to shut down. Plus, I don’t always know what would actually help, so I just end up stuck in the same cycle night after night.

That feeling of constant stress must be exhausting, especially when it seems like your mind won’t give you a break, even when you’re trying to relax. You’re navigating a lot, and it's tough not knowing what would truly help. What would be different for you if you could find a way to break out of this cycle?

If I could break out of this cycle, I think I’d feel more rested and able to think clearer during the day. It’d probably help me focus better at work and maybe even ease some of the stress I’m feeling about my job. I just want to feel like I’m in control again, instead of my worries controlling me.

Regaining control over your thoughts and feeling rested and clear-headed during the day sounds really important to you. It could make a big difference in how you handle work stress and life overall. Since those changes could mean so much to you, what do you think might be a first step toward getting closer to those feelings of control and clarity?

Honestly, I’m not sure where to even start. That's part of why I’m here—I’m hoping you can help me figure out what that first step could be. I know I need to do something, but it feels really overwhelming right now.

It makes sense to feel overwhelmed when you're unsure where to begin, especially with so much on your plate. It’s a big step just to reach out and express that you're ready to work toward change. Before exploring possible steps, is there anything else about your experience you'd like to talk through?
I think that’s really it. I’m just feeling stuck, overwhelmed, and unsure of how to move forward.

Thank you for sharing all of this. Here's what has stood out during our conversation: you're feeling stuck in a cycle of stress and sleeplessness, driven by worries about work and taking care of your family. What's most important to you is reclaiming a sense of control, feeling rested, and being able to focus more clearly during the day. Would it feel okay to start talking about some small steps that might help you move toward those goals?
Yeah, I guess that would be okay. I’d like to try something, even if it’s small, to see if it helps.

That’s a great place to start—just trying something small to see if it helps. What kinds of things do you feel you could realistically try? For example, would it help to explore ways to unwind during the evening, reduce stress, or focus on sleep habits? What do you think would feel most manageable to begin with?

Maybe I could try cutting back on using my phone before bed—it seems like that’s not helping much anyway. I’m not really sure what else would work for me, but I’m willing to try small changes if it means getting some sleep and clearing my head a bit.

Cutting back on using your phone before bed sounds like a thoughtful step, especially since you’ve noticed it might not be helping with sleep. Starting with one small change like that can be a good way to see if it makes a difference. Would you like help brainstorming other calming activities or routines you could try before bed?

Cutting back on phone use before bed is a great choice—you’re already identifying something that might make a difference. Maybe you could replace it with something relaxing, like reading a book, listening to calming music, or doing some deep breathing exercises. Would any of those feel doable for you?

Those ideas sound like good options to try—especially if they help you wind down without adding to stress. Deep breathing exercises are simple and can help calm racing thoughts. Which one of these feels most natural for you to try alongside cutting back on phone use?
